dialogues.text: Missed it!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We’re even. (back to the conversation) Yeah... Ray’s got 45 years ina row... big cakes.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Woah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m coming up on four myself, you know that right?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: That’s crazy. Otis drops a sock.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Alright go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Ten?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yup. Ten. Otis starts doing push-ups.  21.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna give me a cake?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: (mid push-ups) Yeah if you want one.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You know what else I want?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: To meet your buddy Tom and make sure he’s not a chicken-hawk. Otis stops doing push-ups and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: He’s not.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I want to make sure he’s not.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: You need to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No you need to trust me! I don’t know why I don’t get to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Mom thinks you’1l get weird.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Your mother thinks a lot of things that aren’t true. Your mother lives in fuckin’ space.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: She’s always been there for me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah she’s been there for you and she’s been at the Renaissance Fair. I’ve been there for you too. I’m the one that gets you up at four in the morning. Who’s the one here now?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: She's busy! She has a job.  Otis sits 22.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Why is she busy? Why does she have a job? Think it through. Play the tape out. down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does your mother have a job for?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: In case what?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: In case you fail. James drops down to eye level with Otis.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In case it don’t work out. oTis No.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes man. She’s filling your head full of fear. I would never do that to you. I pump you full of strength! Because we’re a team and I know you got what it takes. You're a fucking star and I know it. That's why I’m here. I’m your cheerleader, honey boy. You trust me?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Okay then! I’1l make you a horse trade. I'll give you this pack of cigarettes--

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: The whole pack?  23.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The whole pack... if you bring him in here. You gotta smoke them in the bathroom though cause I don’t want people to think I’m a shit father.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: No one thinks you’re a shit father.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No one thinks I’m a shit father? You're mother thinks I’m a shit father.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: That’s in your head.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Tom thinks I’m a shit father.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: That’s also in your head.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How do you think you get in the big brother program? Huh? What’s the main reason?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: There is no main reason.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah there is a main reason. You gotta have a shit father. oTis No...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes you do. And your mother is advertising what a shit father I am every time you go to these fuckin’ Dodger games or paint ball or dirt bike or whatever it is you’re doing. And look, I got four years sober son... four years is REAL. You bring him over here and how about this, I'll barbecue for him? Otis isn’t sure.  24.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just a start... just planting seeds ya’ know? Come on man. You gotta let me in a little bit!

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Just a barbecue?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah... He hands Otis the pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Okay. (smiling) I’ll ask but it doesn’t mean he’s going to come. James holds Otis’s face in celebration.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Thank you! That’s all I’m asking you to do! James gets up, mission accomplished...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want a soda?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. And heads out of the room. Otis stays on the bed looking over the cigarette in his h He looks for a lighter but can’t find one. He puts the cigarette behind his ear and starts folding the forgotten laundry on the bed. CLOSE ON: Otis’s face staring into the lens, the glow of motel T.V flickering off his face. ON THE SCREEN: James, in clown face, in a desert. He’s looking into the camera while performing with his chicken top of his hat.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (on TV) And now, ladies and gentleman, boys and girls, performing live, Henrietta Lafowl, world’s first daredevil chicken.  25. With the chicken still on his head, James turns away from camera to face the desert. He does a headstand while Henrietta climbs his back to st and stand on his butt. James, now standing on his head, with his chicken resting his butt, looks directly into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Henrietta Lafowl! World’s first daredevil chicken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis wakes up breathing heavy from a dream. He looks over and sees Percy still asleep. He’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis alone in the gym aggressively running full speed in underwear. A physical therapist walks in and watches him. Writes something in his pad and leaves. Otis cranks up the speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft music playing. A group of twelve clients floating in the pool. Some are being held by others. Otis watches from the sides. ALEC (30s), caucasian Anger Management Coach, gives his “Anger management coach exercises” to the group while eye Otis. We get the sense Alec’s calm exterior seems to hide suppressed interior.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Can I get everyone’s attention please. We’re going to do a small trust exercise, okay? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALEC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're just going to grab your partner, good, now you just switch... Alec keeps his eyes focused on Otis who can only manage t look away from the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis is eating alone. In front of him knitting needles and a ball. He pushes them further and further away as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Moreno sits in a swivel chair while Otis paces back a forth.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: What is this? What are you trying to do? You can’t have me in the fucking room knitting for two hours!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORENO
dialogues.text: What are your SUDS right now?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORENO
dialogues.text: Okay let’s bring it down. I want you to name four objects and let them bring you to the present moment—— We watch Otis’s eyes pick four things.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Door! Vase! Lightbulb--

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORENO
dialogues.text: Snap the rubber-band with each item.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Shoe! (snap) Shoe! (snap) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shoe! (snap) Shoe!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORENO
dialogues.text: One more. Otis contains his frustration. But it shows.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Door. He slaps the door.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORENO
dialogues.text: Let’s try again. Name four things and let them bring you back into the room. He can’t look at her again when he talks. oTis No. He continues to pace the room upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis and Percy retrieve eggs and place them in constructi buckets.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: You know chickens outnumber humans 3 to 1? They’re gonna take over the world, we gotta do something about this! Otis stops shoveling and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s a true fact. You can look it up. They get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis and Percy are in their beds. The room mirrors the Mo Percy shares the fruit he saved from lunch. Otis eats it.  28.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: ...You don’t pray before you eat?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: No... After.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: Why? He takes another bite.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I’m fucking with you. I don’t. He goes to brush his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door and stares at himself in the mirror as starts to pee. He watches himself as he listens to the sound of his urin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis wakes up but stays in bed for a second to stare at t ceiling. He gets up and packs a few things. He waits for the coffe maker with the shades drawn. Light creeping in through th slit. He pops a CD in his walkman and looks at the dust s in the light. He sees James sleeping in his bed. Otis places a hot cup of coffee by his glasses and a smal wrapped up gift. He rubs his hand across his dad’s bare-feet to stir him a and then grabs his backpack and goes. Door closes. James's eyes open. He grabs the gift and opens it. It’s a Scratch N’ Sniff watch. He scratches. And Sniffs.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James sits by the door with his coffee and works on bendi two Paper Clips into a lock opener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patches of green the city waters on large sprinkler syste James looks over his shoulder and PICKS THE LOCK to the L riverbank’s gate behind the Free-Way. James lays his bike up and opens his side-saddle. He pull out a bright “Adopt-A-Highway” safety vest, hard hat, glo a pick-up stick, goggles and a white trash bag. He walks and over to the bank of the freeway and lowers to a knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chandler Lodge’s Moto-Meeting Stag. Eighteen men in chair sit in a circle under an awning smoking cigarettes. A few who are not club related. Lawyers, a few Dads, an o Veteran, two twenty-something's from a band, all encircli Folger's can by the twelve or so motorcycles in the back. CRAIG (late 40s), looks like a man who has been scraping bottom longer than the top, is in the midst of a share... James watches him like a hawk.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I guess I’m here because of my old Man... He was a preacher. A bullshitter basically. A liar. A thief. But mainly he was never there for me. He was doing his own thing. And I thought wow, good, well cool for him. But what about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis sits alone in his trailer in pajamas. He opens the d and looks but no one is there. He heads back inside and s down and lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig continues his share.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Nobody was there so I thought I’11 drink it out. Getting shit-faced worked... ya know? It worked like a charm. Took away the “cut and dried” feeling... For a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James kneels down and digs into the soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James adjusts his posture to look taller than Craig. Like little kids do when they take pictures together.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So I ran with that because what else was offered. Church? God? Yes... But that didn’t quite work for me... It’s bullshit really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis, still alone, looking to see if his ride is coming..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig still sharing. James still watching him.  31.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I thought if God was real, he built me with a question that only I can answer. And that’s what you have to do. You have to answer that question yourself. You have to do it yourself. You’ve gotta ultimately save yourself. James gets uncomfortable and looks around to see if anyon else is hearing this... He checks Craig.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, what book were you reading?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I know what the book says but what I am saying is what’s honest with me-—

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It says we came to believe, partner. Why don’t you read the fucking book again? I can’t do it anymore, man. He stands and leaves while shouting over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You guys are gonna keep signing up for this shit why don’t you just sign up for the Kool-Aid committee cause all you fuckers are drinking it. James leaves the meeting still yelling.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you write your own fucking book, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You’re not alone brother!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. I needed a fucking meeting today! And they let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis stands around still waiting when a PA in a golf cart pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: PA
dialogues.text: You got a ride Otis?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah my dad is just over there getting his bike...

dialogues.speaker: PA
dialogues.text: You sure? I didn’t see him on set today.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah he was here... yep.

dialogues.speaker: PA
dialogues.text: Well good work today. Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. See ya! She drives away. Otis waits til she is out of sight and t starts to walk home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Otis walk holding hands. As they approach a TACO TRUCK and its line of customers, James recoils and lets go. Now at the truck, Otis hands him some money.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I‘1l get chicken tacos. Two please. James approaches the window.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I‘1l get four chicken tacos. You got Horchata up there? A girl sees Otis and whispers to her friend. They turn an stare. James clocks it.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit. They recognize you. Sometimes I wish I was you, man.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Course.... Be famous, people chasing me with cameras and shit, Women... Not these junk whores... you know, good ones.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: What’s a good one?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Dolly Parton type. Woman with a strategy. Otis actually laughs now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s funny bout that Otis? Dolly Parton's got her shit together. You know she’s got her own theme park? James grabs their food and hands Otis his tray.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ain’t got a fucking theme park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis is asleep inside the room. James is sitting outside. Smoking. Alone. Little Q is back from another long night. She puts her bag inside the room and sits outside to smok cigarette. James gets up and walks past the grassy area between thei rooms. He starts to perform a small clowning/Mime routine for he She watches for a while and smiles at him. He finishes and bows to her.  34. When he looks up she’s gone into the room. INT/EXT. TOM’S CAR / VISTA MOTEL PARKING LOT - AFTERNOON A beautiful yellow HOT ROD TRUCK pulls into the driveway Otis in the passenger seat. He’s in a Dodger hat, holding a signed ball by Nomo. Driver is TOM (35), A strong chinned Hispanic man dressed casually in a leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: So uh... he doesn’t really like the Big Brothers program so just don’t bring it up and stuff if that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh okay. Tom apprehensively waves to James who is outside watching them park.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Wow. Nice car.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey thanks. I’m Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake as Otis gets out and runs off to the room with bag.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m his father.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Beautiful truck. You do the work on her?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sure did.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Pop it! Go ahead. Tom pops the hood.  Otis runs 35.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 292 huh?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is actually the 352. 5.8 Liter.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Right. Y-blocks, that’s the 292...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Y-block 292 to 272, that was the big engine in the T-bird.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s right, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Then they upgraded in ‘65 to the 352 cubic.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ pretty man.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you brother.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Sits low four a 4x4 isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s the original coil springs on the I-beam.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well all 64 trucks had leaf springs in ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You don’t say? back out in his swim trunks and heads to the pool.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You going swimming partner?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah it’s hot...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Smart. (to Tom) You good in that coat boss?  36.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yea. I’m good, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Ok... They follow Otis to the pool. Talking as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what FORD stands for don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s the old man’s last name. Henry Ford.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s it stand for?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Found on the road dead. James laughs. Tom is polite. Otis keeps walking ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis gets in the water. We stay with him watching them nervously as they get to know each other.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So you working for the FBI or something?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No nothing like that, that’s a little out of my pay-grade. I’ma passport specialist.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh what’s that? State Department? What the fuck you doin’ over there?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I majored in telecommunications, I'm half Mexican... so I’ve got a vested interested in fighting discrimination here in the city...  37.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s fantastic. (to Otis) Hey go get some soda and the ketchup! Otis hops out of the water. James tosses him the keys to their room. Tom sits.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're saying you're an idealist? Yeah, man. That’s cool, I know a little bit about that. Like, uh, ‘I don’t know where I’m going but I’m on my way there!' Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Alright, take a seat man, we got a little time. James sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Woo, sun in your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well it’s good having you here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I appreciate it man. I’ve heard all about ya.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So what’s your story Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m from Detroit. I still have both my parents... twin sister... Graduated from Calvin in Grand Rapids...  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis runs out across the lot to the soda machine. We go w him. He passes the Vista maid doing the rounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis arrives. Little Q and Mama DJ are in a tense argumen nearby. Little Q’s shoulder is bruised. He listens in while pretending to look for his money.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA DJ
dialogues.text: Get outta my face! Mama DJ leaves. Otis starts to put quarters in the soda machine. Once Mam is gone, Little Q unearths a pack of cigarettes hidden un the soda machine. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I like your Jellies.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE Q
dialogues.text: Jellies? Otis points at her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE Q, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. Like a business man, Otis puts his hand out for a handsha

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I’m Otis. I live over there in number 6. He’s twelve. It’s strange. She grabs it and begins to THUMB WRESTLE. She wins. She k his thumb under hers for a_ little longer. He’s uncomfortable. She smiles and lets go. She takes out a cigarette but see it’s broke down the center. Otis, soda now in hand, notic

dialogues.speaker: OTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Wait right here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is manning the grill.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So Calvin is a big school. I know that. They got a basketball program. That’s an expensive school isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I had a little help.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Got to! How the fuck you swing that man? Shit, Mexican, come from poverty. Gotta be hard as fuck to get in there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Lot of hard work...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You get some kinda Spanish grant or something? Otis approaches and listens in for the right moment to disturb.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: (to Tom) Hey, are you good?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m good Otis thanks.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: (to James) Dad can I bum a smoke? James hands him one.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hang on to your butts. Tom knows he can’t interject but “what the fuck”. Otis ru off. We stay with James and Tom as he re-composes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Love that kid.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s a great kid...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I think that’s why the Big Brother program is so important. To have more voices to listen to.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Sure I’1l bet. James plops a plate of burgers on the table and sits down

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this father figure--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I had a strong voice and now I have a chance to pay it forward. Help out when I can. James leans forward to look Tom in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s good on you. I appreciate you Tom. I know my son appreciates you also. He likes you. I can see it on his face. James goes to light a cigarette then stops.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet if you went over there right now and asked that boy who he wants to be when he grows up, he wouldn’t say me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No? James lights the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Would he say you, Tom? James stares into his soul.  41.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s not about that for me James...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What’s it about for you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Giving back. Letting somebody know you are there for them. Being of service.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No I know about that cause I doa little bit of service myself. I got about four years sober.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That’s good. James laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s great.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It is great isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’ve seen a lot of lives get ruined...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s tough.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can only imagine.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: One day at a time man... Look I don’t know what you’ve heard about me Tom, but I know what you haven’t heard about me. What you haven’t heard about me is that if I catch you around my son again, in any capacity whatsoever, I will skull fuck your well-adjusted twin sister’s carcass on top of your casket until my dick runs through the back of her half-Mexican brain plate. You hear what the fuck I’m saying?  42. Tom gets up to walkaway. James shoots up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: What if they catch you again?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Who is ‘they’?

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: The police. The city.  84.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The city? They water it for me... no trail. This crop works you and me are going to build a tree house on the fucking moon. Trust me honey boy, I’m your father. Otis smiles, “ok”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Otis ride on the bike. Otis holds onto his dad closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis keeps walking towards the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You know the older you get you learn a couple of things about life. You get to know what you come from. Now you come from a line of alcoholics, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Otis pull up to his crop on the side of the freeway. Bike parked. Otis is wearing the bright yellow “Adopt-A- Highway” vest.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You wanted a tree house? Otis surveys the plants and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes sir... Man of my word. Otis runs through the greenery.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get in there! It’s yours.  85. Otis kneels and holds a plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis keeps after the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A long line of good people who were hurting and didn’t know what the fuck to do so they drank a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James leans in close by Otis.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: It’s sticky!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s magical stuff right there. That’s god, pecker-wood. Our boys are in a world of their own. James puts his arm Otis. It is as affectionate as we’ve ever seen them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis watches the chicken cross the road. He continues aft it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every single one of us got a grudge. Every single one of us got somebody that fucked us over. I know you got one. You gotta lay the grudge down. Or it’s going to fucking kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis follows the chicken into the lot he grew up in. He w towards his dad’s bike. He sees the door to their room is open.  86. James appears in the doorway dressed in FULL CLOWN COSTUM He waves to Otis then starts to perform a miming routine. Otis stands there frozen and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis and James sit on the side of the freeway. Otis betwe his father’s legs. James holds a joint in Otis’s mouth. We stay on him as he blows a cloud of SMOKE... And then i comes. A PAINFUL COUGH. A proud James smiles and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You know a seed has to totally destroy itself to become a flower... And doing that is a violent act, honey boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis approaches James in the clown costume. A tense moment. They hug. A big hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James hugging young Otis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis and James sit with their legs in the pool. James’s c costume, makeup, and shoes still on. He turns to his son.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Nobody is mad at me anymore.  87.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s all I ever wanted. The chicken walks by them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll get there too. He hands Otis a lit joint. Otis inhales and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to make a movie about you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're making a movie about me? Otis nods, “yeah”.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, Make me look good honey boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boys cut through it like a crazy knife on wheels. Otis and James are gliding down the freeway. It’s a tight operation. Otis at the helm, James holds tight. He moves his son. Hugs him at 120 mph. Full Speed Love. CLOSE ON: Otis in the front this time around. High rises bulging through the thick haze of Los Angeles smog. The Sierra Madres bitching in the distance. Our boys flying down the freeway. It’s an expert working unit. Only they know where they’re going... Until we realize it’s just Otis on the bike.
